name: TheAtlantic
text: "Backlashes appear as seemingly serial and discrete events—against the civil-rights movement in the 1960s, or the women’s movement in the ’70s, or the gay-rights movement in the ’90s. But this obscures an underlying continuity," @LarryGlickman writes. https://t.co/LnK3UaupA0

name: TheAtlantic
text: With varying lockdowns in place, and safety measures enacted by local communities, the Muslim holy month of Ramadan has been observed very differently around the world this year. From @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/KE9Nv3by39

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos of the Week: Skiing in the French Alps, flooding in Michigan, drive-thru burlesque in Las Vegas, disinfecting streets in Buenos Aires, social distancing rings in Turkey, a fawn rescue in Germany, and much more—via @TheAtlPhoto. https://t.co/Kd1oNg68WE

name: TheAtlantic
text: We’re going to be wearing masks for a while, but they make social interactions hard. So some experts are suggesting we wear face shields instead, writes @olgakhazan: https://t.co/GY3EAnQ8Rm

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: On the latest episode of the "Social Distance" podcast, @jameshamblin and @katlwells ask infectious-disease expert Stephen Thomas to explain the medical and ethical issues involved in developing a new vaccine. https://t.co/MEIwLUQYJW

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Universities face a nightmare this fall. Plus: some advice for the class of 2020. The latest Atlantic Daily, by @mimbsy and @isabelfattal:
https://t.co/07JbyYsdRk

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Completely protecting children from harm is impossible, but the available evidence suggests that, for most children in the United States, the risk of COVID-19 at summer camp is very modest," @ZekeEmanuel, @amayahdiana, and @Aaron_Glickman write. https://t.co/IVC25KXOgx

name: TheAtlantic
text: China has used the cover of the pandemic to take Hong Kong's autonomy, @TMclaughlin3 writes. It's one of several aggressive actions by Beijing across the region. https://t.co/52BmljzYe4

name: TheAtlantic
text:
1/ Happy Friday! We’ve got a roundup of some recent hits from our writers that you might have missed. 

Read these stories and more in our iOS app, where our editors guide you through the best of The Atlantic’s journalism every day. Download it here: https://t.co/QKOJcmtBgO

name: TheAtlantic
text:
2/ “I’m not a thief or a spy myself. I’m a journalist. Was I just being paranoid?”

After @bartongellman met Edward Snowden in 2013, his life changed. Read about his years spent under near-constant stress and surveillance. https://t.co/5twJsXtZOz

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/ Cheering is a more important part of sports than you might realize. Athletes playing “ghost games” in empty arenas for fans at home will need a whole new mindset to compete as intensely as before, @dannychau reports. https://t.co/IE6wu0tQ0r

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ Elon Musk has been downplaying the pandemic on and off social media, including making pushes to reopen his plants. To his fans, he’s beginning to look “less like humankind’s savior and more like a ruthless industrialist,” @marinakoren writes. https://t.co/IRj96Es0jS

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ When will we know if states that reopened early made a mistake in doing so? The answer, @AmandaMull writes, is: not until it’s too late. https://t.co/OYHvfonXrd

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/ Cheering is a more important part of sports than you might realize. Athletes playing “ghost games” in empty arenas for fans at home will need a whole new mindset to compete as intensely as before, @dannychau reports. https://t.co/IE6wu0tQ0r

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ Elon Musk has been downplaying the pandemic on and off social media, including making pushes to reopen his plants. To his fans, he’s beginning to look “less like humankind’s savior and more like a ruthless industrialist,” @marinakoren writes. https://t.co/IRj96Es0jS

name: TheAtlantic
text:
"In war, it is generals who vie with prime ministers and presidents for power and affection; today it is chief medical officers," @TomMcTague writes.
https://t.co/GfFDvpPDJc

name: TheAtlantic
text: The pandemic has silenced the campaign to lead North Carolina, a major presidential swing state, @russellberman reports. https://t.co/Fv2sOKULV2

name: TheAtlantic
text: "As an indoor person myself—and a lover of theater, sports, and restaurants—it’s painful to think about the range of activities that will be pinched in the next year," @DKThomp writes. https://t.co/KhuQ3QOV0x

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Books Briefing: Twenty titles for all your warm-weather moods. https://t.co/CwobmfaXaq

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @jpinsk: Graduating into a recession could set the class of 2020 back financially and professionally for years.

My latest in @TheAtlantic is about how they're coping and what their options are at the moment:

https://t.co/8LnU9Gtkkw

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: China has used the cover of the pandemic to take Hong Kong's autonomy, @TMclaughlin3 writes. It's one of several aggressive actions by Beijing across the region: https://t.co/1W60h8CTuw

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @olgakhazan: My mom would like all the women who got their lips done to know she's sorry you wasted your money https://t.co/lCeviNvn99

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TMclaughlin3: The stock market plunged, interest in VPNs shot up, and Hong Kongers wondered whether 2047, the year in which China was set to take back full control of the city, had arrived more than two decades early. “I’m heartbroken,” Tanya Chan, said.  https://t.co/PH05ULi4iR

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @nora_kelly: .@russellberman: "A race once expected to be close is looking—for the moment—more like a romp." https://t.co/JkhdzBXlOl

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @DKThomp: I wrote about the science of COVID's indoor vs. outdoor transmission, and what it means for the future of the great indoors, including:

- offices
- restaurants and retail
- theaters 
- arenas
- bars and clubs
- gyms and fitness centers

https://t.co/P3G3NceQxP

name: TheAtlantic
text: Doctors are concerned about an emerging crisis in mental health. @jameshamblin investigates what can be done. https://t.co/LvG2ShTLzx

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @PaulBisceglio: “This has the effect of altering the social norm by which depression and other conditions are defined. Essentially, this throws off the whole definitional rubric.”

https://t.co/gIWpeKSmS4 by @jameshamblin

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @jameshamblin: Symptoms of depression are suddenly much more common than usual. All need to be taken seriously. I wrote about how mental-health professionals are navigating that in a system that can't even address all the need in normal times. https://t.co/vOeavxGy80

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @SStossel: "Millions of people exhibiting signs of depression now have to discern ennui from temporary grieving from a medical condition." https://t.co/toBUHMPVmp

name: TheAtlantic
text: The economic scars of graduating into a recession—higher rates of unemployment (for high-school graduates) and lower earnings (for everyone) compared with peers graduating a year or two earlier or later—can last for 10 or 15 years, @jpinsk writes. https://t.co/vIRfvFvPKI

name: TheAtlantic
text: China has used the cover of the pandemic to take Hong Kong's autonomy, @TMclaughlin3 writes. It's one of several aggressive actions by Beijing across the region. https://t.co/Z24tylL6hG

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Adults need to help [children] regain normalcy. One way to do that is by opening summer camps as soon as possible," @ZekeEmanuel, @amayahdiana, and @Aaron_Glickman write. https://t.co/1QpO6WAp2Z
